content:
normally all you would need is the roaming profile. The local stuff should only be cached information

However as you have tinkered with what I am guessing are account "local directories" I suggest you check those in account settings to determine what you have changed them to so you get them all.

Personally I would have moved the profile in the first place. You have used the really easy way to move you data location and now you pay the price of your earlier expedience in changing per account settings instead of the location of the profile.

.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I was not aware Thunderbird had a message that told you your settings were out of date. Are you sure this was not some setting generated by your antivirus program?

So now instead of trying to fix your accounts, we are trying to set them up anew without the original error message or anything to indicate what the original error message was about or what the problem is. If you wanted to make a difficult job harder, you have achieved that.

Almost every instance I have even seen of this sort of error on setting up a new account where the settings are for a major provider that Thunderbird would have detected from it's database and then could not connect to was a direct result of a failed antivirus product, the remainder were VPN related as they do not play well with email.

Start your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

Now try and add your mail account to Thunderbird. Note that a wired internet connection is required for at least Windows safe mode with networking. So plug your laptop in to the router before you try. WiFi will not be available.

This process should load windows without your antivirus, without your VPN and without any of the normal startup programs, many of which can cause connectivity issues.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Please provide more information on your situation. Is this a signin code? We cannot offer suggestions without knowing what happened. A screenshot of your incoming server settings pane may help as well as any error messages.

content:
could it be you have consumed the allowable 5 concurrent connections on a single mail server? That is are they all say @gmail.com email addresses? There is no practical limit, but if you have say 5 accounts checking for messages every minute I could see exactly what your a saying happening. The sixth and subsequent connection attempt failing. I see this occasionally on Startup with outlook accounts.

Fundamental email is not an instant messaging platform, despite a lot of people acting like it is.

creator: T-bird1539

content:
Thunderbird Support said
Spoke with Nord, they were unable to give me guidance other than to try all the things I already had. They are not blocking POP/IMAP, and SMTP protocols. Also tried split tunneling and that didn't work either.

Have you considered that Google may be refusing you? You have a VPN that is reporting you to be where i the world? And you have a phone without Nord that reports to to be somewhere very different to where NORD is dropping you off. What this is not is a Thunderbird issue. What this is, is a VPN issue.

It is quite simple, if it works without NORD, then the issue is not Thunderbird. It might be your antivirus, it might be your backup solution. But the only common factor you have identified is your VPN.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Subject: Re: Missing Emails – Let’s Get Them Back

Dear Chris,

I’m very sorry for your loss. I understand how important these emails are to you, and I’ll do my best to help.

First, just to check—are you using Firefox to access webmail (like Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook) or a separate email app (like Thunderbird, Outlook, or Apple Mail)?

If you’re using a webmail service: 

   Check the Trash or Archive folder – Sometimes emails are moved there by mistake.    Try using the search bar – If you remember a subject line or name, searching might help.    Log in from another device – If you have another computer or phone that was also used for email, check if the emails are there.

If you were using an email program (like Thunderbird): 

   Let me know the name of the email app you were using.    If your husband had backups set up, I can guide you on restoring them.

No worries—we’ll take this step by step. Please reply with any details you can, and I’ll help you as best as I can.

Warm regards,Sakura.
creator: Sakura

content:
Kedves Attila!

A leírásod alapján nekem úgy tűnik, hogy nem a Thunderbirdben lesz a hiba, ugyanis az alapból sehova sem pakolja a leveleket, csak megjelöli őket (láng ikon a listában).

Mindenesetre a Thunderbird saját levélszemét-kezelését úgy tudod kikapcsolni, hogy a Beállítások -> Adatvédelem és biztonság -> Levélszemét szakaszában az Üzenetek olvasottnak jelölése alatt kikapcsolod a Ha a Thunderbird jelöli levélszemétnek, továbbá az egyes postafiókok alatt a Levélszemét lapon kikapcsolod az Adaptív levélszemét-kezelés engedélyezése ehhez a postafiókhoz lehetőséget (és esetleg a Szolgáltató levélszemétszűrőjének elfogadása lehetőséget, ha van ilyen a postafiókhoz).

Ha ezek mind megvannak, akkor maga a Thunderbird nem végez semmilyen levélszűrést, de ettől függetlenül még a postafiókod lehet hogy csinál ilyet. Például a mailboxos levelezésemet SpamAssassinnal ellenőrzi a szolgáltatóm.

Milyen postafiókról van szó, nem lehet hogy valójában nálad is erről van szó?

Üdv, Balázs
creator: meskobalazs

A version for 136 is in the works:

In the meantime, Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, copy the mbox into Mail/Local Folders, restart TB, find the folder under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.

content: From your picture, the Archived-002 and Sent-003 files haven't completely downloaded, hence the .part extension. Once the download is complete, you should see files named Archived-002.mbox and Sent-003.mbox with non-zero sizes. Remove the .mbox extension so they have the same format as Trash and Unsent Messages, both of which are mbox files of Type File (remove it also from Inbox-004.mbox and fredericamg@gmail.com.mbox).

content:
Can you post a link to where it says IEEE accounts can't be accessed in TB? I found this article, which indicates that accounts can be added just like any other domain using google servers, e.g. with these settings:

incoming IMAP server: imap.gmail.com, port 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = user@ieee.org

outgoing SMTP server: smtp.gmail.com, port 465, SSL/TLS, or 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = user@ieee.org

Open the account in webmail and enable IMAP (should be enabled by default).

There are many other free mail services, such as outlook.com, Yahoo, AOL, GMX, all of which are popular with TB users.
creator: sfhowes
